Expectation1: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation1: The project is still in exploratory discussions, and alternative approaches can be proposed later
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: The main protest march is beginning in a few minutes, and you are needed at the front to lead the first chant.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, the hum of the office a distant background to my racing thoughts. As an engineer, I was expected to contribute ideas for the new project, even though we were still in the early stages. My manager had just asked me to stay for an impromptu brainstorming session—he wanted fresh perspectives, and I knew my input could shape the direction we’d take. But my phone buzzed with urgent messages from my activist group. The main protest march was about to begin, and I was supposed to be at the front, leading the first chant, setting the tone for the demonstration. My friends were counting on me to help raise awareness for a cause I deeply believed in. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing down on me—my team at work expecting technical leadership, my fellow activists needing my voice. My heart pounded as I stared at the clock, torn between two parts of myself, knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
